title: ASX ends flat after uneven day
text:
Other commodities lost value, such as iron ore – receding 2.9 per cent to $US110.81 an ounce – and crude oil, which was down 0.2 per cent to $US58.20 a barrel.

This unevenness in commodities had been one of the consistencies of the market in recent months, QV Equities said in its investor update.

"The growth outlook for many companies remains modest and the environment for most of them fairly challenging," the listed investment company said.

"The trend towards further stimulus and monetary easing from the world’s central banks only serves to highlight the softening economic growth conditions across

most of the globe."

Fortescue Metals followed the sliding trajectory with a 1.2 per cent retreat to $8.46, alongside BHP's decline to $35.07, a loss of 0.2 per cent.

Also negative was financial services company AMP, where shares slid 0.3 per cent to a record low close of $1.60 on confirmation it would merge its banking and wealth divisions. Big banks Commonwealth Bank and National Australia Bank were down less than half a per cent to $78.10 and $28.02 respectively.

Trade talks stall and hit markets

Their lousy day came as junior-level United States-China trade talks reportedly stalled in Washington ahead of more senior negotiations later in the week.

Advertisement

The South China Morning Post reported that Chinese delegates looked likely to leave Washington without any firm groundwork for the minister-level talks that are due to be held on Thursday and Friday (Washington time).

The two superpowers have been embroiled in a bitter trade war that has seen US President Donald Trump impose a variety of tariffs on Chinese imports.

The news hit American stock futures, with Dow futures down 0.2 per cent at 26,265 points, S &P 500 futures down 0.2 per cent at 2914.8 points, and Nasdaq futures down 0.1 per cent at 7692 points heading into the Wall Street open.

Meanwhile, the Australian dollar was on the rise and gained 0.3 per cent to buy US67.5¢.

However, despite the significant losses and negative international news, the packaging industry did its best to stem the losses.

Brambles, armed with a first-quarter trading update showing sales revenue reaching $1.16 billion in the period, shot up 3.5 per cent to $11.40.

Orora charged ahead 13.9 per cent to $3.11 a share on the news it had sold its Australasian fibre business to Japanese manufacturer Nippon Paper Industries for $1.7 billion.

The deal saw industrials advance 0.2 per cent to become one of just five sectors that rose in value on Thursday.

Advertisement

The others were consumer staples, telecommunications, finance, and health industries.

On the consumer staples front, Woolworths was up 0.8 per cent to $37.02 and Wesfarmers rose 0.7 per cent to $38.96.

Telstra advanced 0.6 per cent to $3.51 and REA group up 1.2 per cent to $110.01.

The health sector found its leaders in Sonic Healthcare, which was marked up 1.2 per cent to $28.54, and PolyNovo, which inflated by 11.9 per cent to $2.54.

In financials, Westpac was up 0.4 per cent to $28.53 and Australia and New Zealand Bank gained 0.3 per cent to $27.18.
description: The Australian sharemarket ended Thursday flat, after substantial gains for packaging companies could not cancel out a turgid day for staple industries.
